sen.j: 百首歌（ひゃくしゅうた）は、数を定めて詠う和歌（定数和歌）のひとつで、100首を単位として詠まれるもの。
sen.e: The set of a hundred poems consists of a unit of 100 poems, being a type of waka composed to make up a set of a predetermined number (set of waka).
The Set of One Hundred Poems (百首歌 Hyakushuta) consists of one hundred poems as a unit, which are a type of waka composed with a predetermined number.

sen.j: 1人で100首を詠んだものと、複数の人が詠んだものを100首集めたものに分けることができる。
sen.e: The set of a hundred poems can be broken down into 2 types including the set of one hundred poems composed by an individual poet and the other which is a collection of a hundred poems composed by a number of poets.

sen.j: 1人で詠んだ百首歌は960年（天徳4年）曾禰好忠の家集「曾丹集」のなかの『百ちの歌』に始まるとされる。
sen.e: It is considered that the first set of a hundred poems by individual poet was百ちの歌 composed in 960 which was included in Sotanshu, the personal collection of poetry of SONE no Yoshitada.
sen.cmt: 『百ちの歌』 －読み・定訳不明
sen.e: It is believed that the first set of one hundred poems by an individual poet was "Hyakuchi no Uta" (百ちの歌) composed in 960 as part of the Sotanshu, the personal poetry collection of SONE no Yoshitada.

sen.j: 複数の歌人による百首歌は、1105年（長治2年）～1106年（長治3年）頃堀河天皇に奏覧された「堀河院御時百首和歌」が最初とされる。
sen.e: It is considered that the first set of a hundred poems written by a number of poets was the One Hundred Waka of the Horikawa-In Era submitted to Emperor Horikawa around 1105 to 1106.

sen.j: 藤原公実ら16人によって進詠されたもので以後の組題による百首歌の手本となった。
sen.e: The One Hundred Waka of the Horikawa-In Era consisted of waka written by 16 poets including FUJIWARA no Kinzane which became the model for the subsequent sets of a hundred poems on set topics.

sen.j: 中世以後は、勅撰和歌集を撰出する際の基礎資料として主要な歌人に百首を詠進させるようになった。
sen.e: Subsequent to the medieval times, it became a practice for leading poets of the time to submit 100 poems as baseline material when selecting waka for the Chokusen Wakashu (waka anthology compiled by Imperial command), whereas, the one hundred poem sequences written by an individual poet were composed for the other purposes such as training and to dedicate to shrines and temples.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Following medieval times, it became a practice for leading poets to submit one hundred poems as baseline material when selecting waka for the Chokusen Wakashu (Imperial Anthology of Japanese Poetry compiled by Imperial command). One hundred poem sequences written by an individual poet, on the other hand, were composed for other purposes, such as training and dedicating them to shrines and temples.
